file_content.text: Uh-huh.
You are my apprentice now. You will do as I say.
You will obey me.
No. The Jedi exist to wipe out evil.
I had hoped we could be friends. Oh well.
Sorry to hear that.
I'm sorry, I was meditating.
Passion, peace. Strength, knowledge. Power, serenity. Victory, harmony. Freedom, the Force.
No, this isn't right. What am I doing? I'm not dark side. I'm not Sith.
You seemed pretty dark side when you sought forbidden knowledge.
You used the holocron.
To gain the knowledge necessary to understand and defeat my enemies.
You seemed pretty dark side when you murdered your enemies in rage.
You killed the assassins.
They were Sith. If I let them live, I'm responsible for all the other people they murder.
Why is it always light and dark, black and white?
What about shades of gray?
As a Jedi, I've sworn to end this war. Even if I have to kill every Sith in the galaxy.
Then you understand that sometimes the ends justify the means.
You'll do whatever it takes?
Of course. Jedi take different paths, but have the same goal: peace.
I thought the Jedi were all about peace.
That doesn't sound Jedi-like.
Such murderous thoughts you have.
You sound so angry.
I didn't say I would enjoy it.
There can never be peace in the galaxy as long as the Sith exist. The Sith thrive on endless war.
On the contrary. The Sith Empire is destroying itself with its ceaseless war-mongering. That is why I want to change it.
Help me change it.
You can't change the dark side.
That won't stop me from trying.
Give me a chance.
There more ways to be Sith than there are to be Jedi. Some of us are quite sane, and capable of seeing that this war benefits no one.
We're not all madmen.
And here I thought the Jedi believed in redemption.
What about redemption?
So let's say you kill all the Sith-- the really important ones, at least. What then?
Don't be rash.
You can't kill them all--and the survivors will bicker amongst themselves.
Someone will fill the power vacuum--maybe someone powerful enough to unite the Sith. You might prefer the evil you know.
So what do you propose? How will you change the Empire?
I can't fight you, but I will never respect you.
I need to talk.
I can't serve you if I can't trust you. If I can't believe in what you're working for.
I try to walk in the light and transform the Empire from within. That's all I can promise.
I want a kinder Empire.
But into what? What kind of Empire do you see?
What do you hope to accomplish by following me?
What do you want?
How unfortunate for you. You don't have a choice.
That's not your call to make.
Maybe not. But that's not the answer the Sith I met on Taris would have given.
I believe you're trying to change the Empire from within. But I need to understand your vision. What kind of Empire do you see?
You can't change the dark side. How do you propose to change an Empire rooted in it?
The Empire needs strong, rational leadership. A rational Empire is a peaceful one.
The Empire needs sane leaders.
And you think you can provide that?
That's why I wanted you at my side. I need your guidance.
I don't know yet.
By any means necessary.
Doing whatever it takes.
I see. I'll follow you, for now. But in training they warned us that in tangling with monsters we risk becoming monsters ourselves.
I will not go against the Jedi teachings, or my conscience, but I'll do what I can.
I've been thinking about the future lately. About us, and about the Empire.
It's clear the Empire won't change overnight. I've accepted that. But what about when we're dead?
That's a long ways off.
I'll be around for a while.
I have many followers. They will carry on my legacy.
I have influence over many.
I prefer not to dwell on such morbid topics.
Already planning my death?
If you would allow it, I would be honored to pass on your legacy to your followers and your children.
And to teach them what I know of the Jedi as well.
That would be excellent.
I'd appreciate that.
I'd rather you not pollute my legacy with Jedi teachings.
Save your Jedi knowledge.
They'll need to understand the Jedi in order to follow the path of galactic peace.
I can't think of anyone I'd rather have guarding my legacy.
I would be honored.
Even if we can't change the Empire now, the next generations will learn from your teachings and follow them.
And how is my handsome Sith Lord doing?
You're very happy today.
Cheerful are we?
I'm doing alright, and you?
Good.
Great. Really great.
Your smiling face always cheers me up.
Better now that I'm with you.
I've been thinking about the future. About us.
So have I. Will you marry me?
Me too. Let's get married.
And what are your thoughts?
What were you thinking?
Oh no. I knew this was coming.
This can't end well.
What do you mean, you knew this was coming? Don't be a tease.
I love you. I want to be with you. To wake up beside you. To protect you from your enemies and laugh with your friends.
I'm sorry if that's blunt. That's how I feel.
I feel the same way.
Me too.
Good. That's all I need.
Marriage isn't really an option, but I want to know I have your commitment.
What do you mean "marriage isn't an option"?
Marriage isn't an option?
For what it's worth, I'll never leave you.
You have it.
And I'm not going anywhere.
Well, I don't know about commitment.
Commitment? Gulp.
Are you asking me to marry you?
Is this a proposal?
I guess you could say that.
In that case, why don't we make our relationship official?
Marry me.
I wish I could.
Technically, I need the Jedi Council's permission to marry.
Why do you still care what the Jedi Council thinks?
No, you don't.
Because I'm still a Jedi.
It's alright. I'd rather not be tied down anyway.
Marriage is over-rated.
Oh really. If you think just because we're not married, you can do whatever you want....
Well, that is the point of not being married isn't it?
Well, sure.
We're still committed to each other.
It was just a joke. Calm down.
Kidding.
Don't be a tease.
There are other ways to get married. Without the Jedi Council's permission.
Who cares what the Jedi say?
Then let's go to the Jedi Council.
So let's get it.
I don't think they'd approve.
We can hope that someday we'll succeed in our mission, that there will be peace between the Empire and the Republic, the Jedi and the Sith.
Maybe then we can get married.
Do you ever think, maybe we're on the wrong side, doing the wrong thing?
I don't think there is a right or wrong side.
It's complicated.
I think I understand. The galaxy is an intricate place. You think you're doing the right thing, but then it has consequences you never imagined.
People do the right things for the wrong motives and the wrong things for the right motives all the time.
I just wish I could make sense of it.
The Sith order is a depraved place, but you can't hide from evil. You have to face it head-on.
All the time.
I agree. It's not enough to seek personal serenity when there's conflict everywhere.
That's what I tried to tell Master Cyman, but he wouldn't listen. But what does his opinion matter? He's just a hermit in a cave.
Morality is how the weak constrain the strong. I am true to myself.
Never.
I think I would have hated you for saying that when we first met. But I can see how the Jedi use rules to keep people from their potential.
Being strong isn't evil. It's how you use that strength that matters.
My lord. I have incredible news!
A group of Jedi have split from the Jedi order. This is the perfect opportunity for us to win allies!
I'm really not interested in any Jedi interference.
I don't want Jedi help.
I'm not looking for direct support. I just want to know that when it's time to negotiate, we have sympathetic people on the other side.
Last time we tried this, it didn't work out so well.
Are you still trying this?
These guys aren't like Master Cyman.
Divide and conquer. I like it.
Sounds good. I'm listening.
Yes, I guess you could put it that way.
Now, these guys aren't like Master Cyman, but I think that actually gives us a chance.
They're hardliners. Very anti-Sith. But their argument with the Jedi is over methods, not aims. Unlike Master Cyman, they say they are willing to do whatever is necessary.
Then they're our kind of Jedi.
Practical Jedi. How rare.
It sounds like they'd be even less likely to support us.
They hate Sith?
They are Jedi. They want peace. We have to at least try to make our case.
I'm still not keen on the idea of begging for support from people who want me dead.
I'd rather my allies liked me.
The main Jedi Council will never deal with a Sith unless he turns to the light. A splinter group is exactly what we need.
I'm going to meet with them. I promise, I won't be long.
My lord. Thank you.
We have new allies in the rogue Jedi. But I couldn't have done it without your training.
What did they say?
Fill me in.
I was sure this would fail like the last time you tried to get a Jedi on our side.
I'm surprised.
I'm not sure how I helped, but I'm glad I did.
You're welcome.
They were skeptical at first. Like Master Cyman, they would not accept me as a Jedi.
But this time I knew what to say. You helped me understand. Sith and Jedi is an arbitrary divide. I don't know what I am, and I don't care.
I told them the Jedi need to be willing to do whatever it takes--even ally with a Sith--to bring peace to the galaxy.
And they didn't laugh you out of the room?
They believed you?
There were some who remained skeptical.
You've learned a lot, apprentice.
Very good.
Not all the Jedi were won over, of course.
I wish I could have been there.
I'm sorry I missed it.
I do too. I'm sure we would have won even more Jedi to our side if they could have met you and read your sincerity for themselves.
Their leader Master Quintis said that he would be "unwise to turn his back on such conviction and determination."
Thank you for letting me meet with them, my lord.
I, I don't know how to say this, but I was wondering if you wanted to. What I mean is, we've been together a while now.
I'm not sure what you're asking.
What are you saying?
I was just thinking we could get away from it all. Take some time together, alone.
Find someplace private, just the two of us?
You want to mess around?
If that's the way you want it.
Sure.
Yes, I'm sure.
I'm not interested in spending any more time with you than I have to.
No, thank you.
Oh, I'm sorry. I guess I read you wrong.
You want quiet time together, away from everyone else?
Let's go somewhere private....
Yes, exactly.
I thought you'd never stammeringly half-ask.
Could you be any more nervous?
Really? Wonderful. Sometimes we're just so busy with our work.
How much time have we really had to ourselves?
Have I told you how much I love you? We need to take time to ourselves more often.
I'm glad you enjoyed yourself.
Are you sure?
I told you I love you.
You need to trust me.
I believe you now.
I don't want to hear another word of doubt from you.
Speak no more of it.
No, of course not.
I'm sorry if I ever doubted us. Nothing so beautiful could be wrong.
I have a question for you, but you must promise not to mock me.
Go ahead. Ask.
I promise.
I can make no such promise.
No guarantees.
I hope this isn't another of your philosophical quandaries.
This doesn't sound good.
No, it's not that at all.
I've never actually played sabacc. Or pazaak. Or any of those kinds of games. I was wondering if you'd teach me?
It would be my pleasure.
Certainly.
Thank you!
That was a lot of fun. I can't believe I'd never played those games before.
I've never played any of those games myself.
I don't know how to play.
Hm. Well, I guess I don't feel so bad then.
You've never played sabacc? Unbelievable!
You don't play games?
I knew you'd mock me. I'm sorry I asked.
I've been thinking more about what Master Cyman said, and I think he was wrong.
He said you weren't a Jedi. It's only natural you disagree.
Of course you do.
Not about me being a Jedi. Well, I mean, of course I'm a Jedi. I don't need a master to certify that.
Are you still worried about what that worthless Jedi said?
Don't let him bother you.
About me being a Jedi? No.
That makes two of us.
Me too.
He believed we were wrong and that you were leading me astray. But he did nothing.
Is there some kind of Jedi prison for straying Padawans?
What was he supposed to do?
Of course he didn't, he was weak. He knew he couldn't do anything.
He sounds pathetic.
You mean you think he should have attacked you?
You wanted him to fight?
That's exactly what I mean. The Jedi's refusal to do what's necessary, to fight, it makes them weak.
The Jedi will never beat the Empire if they won't take the offensive. And they'll never win peace either, if the Empire can't respect them.
Peace is a noble goal, but it's not a means to an end.
So you're saying "Peace is a lie"?
Sounds like the Sith code.
When it comes to making real change? Yes, I guess I am.
In that particular instance, maybe, but this is a pretty strong reversal for you.
I wouldn't go that far.
No? Could the Sith have surprised us at Coruscant if the Jedi and Republic had been prepared to strike first?
You are becoming a very good little Sith.
I couldn't agree more.
I am not Sith, but I'm not sure I'm Jedi anymore.
A war rages and Master Cyman meditates in his clearing.
Personal peace is one thing, but apathy, inaction--these things are unacceptable.
I don't know how to say this, but I think we should take a break.
Are you splitting up with me?
This sounds like a break-up.
No. I don't know.
Why, what's wrong?
What do you mean?
It's hard for me to explain.
It's not you. It's just, our relationship flies in the face of the Jedi order, the Jedi code.
We take a break when I say so.
No. Absolutely not.
No, I can't do this anymore. You're a Sith. It's against the Jedi code.
I just need time to think things through.
I thought you were past this Jedi code nonsense.
No. Stop toying with me, Jedi.
It's not nonsense. Unless you're calling my life nonsense. Because the Jedi code is the way I've lived my whole life.
I'm sorry if I hurt you. I didn't mean to. But I don't know how else to live.
We love each other. Don't let the Jedi code get in the way of that.
What is there to think about?
I know, but it's not that easy. The Jedi code is my life.
I don't want to lose you, but I'm scared.
I want you to be comfortable.
Take your time.
Just tell me everything's going to be alright, and I'll believe you.
Everything's going to be alright.
Okay.
Alright. I trust you.
Ssh. That's enough talking. Let me show you how much I love you.
Let's go somewhere quiet....
I'm sorry, I'm not ready. I love you, I do.
I'm tired of your hesitation.
Don't deny me.
Then you'll show me how much you love me.
Prove it.
I'm sorry. I just can't. Not right now.
We can wait until you're ready.
It's alright.
Thank you. I'm sorry.
Let me know when you're done panicking.
Enough whining.
I... I'm sorry. Can we start over?
No. I don't have the patience for your angst.
Forget it.
I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.
Of course. I love you.
Yes.
I love you too. I guess that's what scared me.
You either love me or you don't.
Make up your mind.
I do love you. I really do. I guess that's what scared me.
My lord! I'm glad you're here. I wanted to read you this letter I received.
I've been writing to my parents. I haven't seen them since I was little.
"Dear Ashara. We're glad to hear you're happy and well. We're very proud that you've become a Jedi. Asher is nearly sixteen and plans to join Republic Special Forces."
"Love, Mom and Dad." I haven't gotten around to telling them that I'm working with a Sith--I'm not sure they'd understand.
You really ought to tell them.
You shouldn't keep secrets.
You think so? We only just started writing, and it's been fifteen years since I last saw them. I guess you're right.
You're not going to ask me to meet them, are you?
Just don't plan a reunion.
No. I was just curious about them. I don't really remember them. I don't think we'll start spending holidays together or anything.
I don't need you spilling my secrets to your family.
Don't write to them.
Well, we haven't seen each other in so long. I don't expect it to be a really close relationship or anything. I'm sorry.
My lord. I know I'm not officially your apprentice, but I wanted to thank you.
I know we've not always seen eye-to-eye, but I've learned so much from you and your example.
You may not always follow the light, but you are good.
A Sith gets a reputation for being good, she loses all respect.
Just don't spread that around.
Don't worry. I can keep a secret.
A Sith gets a reputation for being good, he loses all respect.
Just don't spread that around.
Aw, you're going to make me cry.
Now you're being sappy.
Don't tease. I'm serious.
I never would've believed a Sith could follow the light, until I met you.
I couldn't do it without you.
Thanks to you.
I'm glad I can help.
You can't judge a person by what they wear or the color of their lightsaber.
It takes all kinds.
You're right. The Jedi teachings about the Sith blinded me.
I feel more at one with the Force than I've ever felt. I have peace, like the Jedi speak of, and freedom like the Sith.
So, thank you.
If you hadn't become Sith, what did you want to be?
I would've settled for "not a slave."
I don't know.
Yeah, I guess I would've felt the same in your shoes.
I always wanted to open my own business. Run a shop, start a family.
An entrepreneur.
I always wanted to be a starship captain.
Space has always appealed.
I guess you got part of what you wanted. This is a pretty nice ship.
I've been thinking about this lately. I was trained to be a Jedi, practically from birth.
Being with you, I'm questioning a lot of things. I'm much more in touch with my emotions, for example.
A beautiful flower like you should not hide.
I'm grateful for that.
Oh no, I wasn't trying to say that at all. I think it's a good thing.
Now's not the time for philosophical conversations. Let's just enjoy each other.
Lighten up a little.
You're right. I'm being silly.
Are the Jedi really that repressed?
Do Jedi really not feel?
No, I wouldn't say repressed. It's just a different way of experiencing the world.
The rules about that sort of thing have gotten lighter over the years. Jedi can marry, with permission. But most remain unmarried by choice.
Would you ever consider getting married?
What about you?
Maybe. If the right person came along.
Now you're just being coy.
Don't tease.
Am I the right person?
What about me?
Would you get married without Jedi Council approval?
What about the Jedi Council?
Let's not worry about that yet.
Why should anyone need anyone else's permission to marry?
Permission? That's disgusting.
For the good of the order. Just like what you do for the good of the Empire.
It's still foolish. The intellect, the body, the emotions--all have their role to play.
Emotions are important.
Mind and body I understand, but I'm still not sure about emotions.
My body tells me that fire burns when I put my hand in it, and my mind remembers so that I don't put my hand in the fire again.
But what role do emotions play?
Emotions interpret your body's sensations. They tell you that pain is bad and pleasure is good.
They help you feel.
Like the goose bumps I get when you touch me?
They give you the impulse to tell the people close to you not to stick their hands in the fire.
They give you empathy.
Compassion. I can see that.
Look, I wasn't trying to start an argument. Let's just enjoy this, hm?
What I mean is, I've never been so happy.
They let you fall in love. Isn't that enough?
You can't love without them.
Well, when you put it that way.
You do make me happy.
Stick with me and we'll make the whole galaxy jealous.
Me neither.
I can't wait.
How about a kiss then?
Show me.
I'd like that.
Now you're just embarrassing me.
You're making me blush.
No one's looking. We can be disgustingly cute and nobody will see.
Yes, I like that very much.
I wonder if it was the right thing. I never really got the chance to choose.
You can do whatever you want now.
This is your chance to choose.
Neither did I, but I fought for my freedom and won it.
I struggled for my chance.
That's why I could never be a Jedi.
I'm glad I'm Sith.
Well, it's not as if the Sith gave you much choice, did they?
I guess I'm still trying to figure out what I want.
I can't believe him. I'm not a Jedi? He says I'm not a Jedi!
Did you meet with Master Cyman? What happened?
What's going on?
Master Cyman!
Of course you're a Jedi. What are you talking about?
Calm down.
There is no emotion. There is no emotion. There is no emotion.
Well, you're quick to anger, stubborn, and you left your training to follow a Sith. I'm not so sure you are a Jedi.
Yeah? You don't act like one.
Shut up. I'm not a Sith.
I came to him for help, and he turned me away.
It's not fair. I was the best Padawan Masters Ryen and Ocera ever trained. I am a Jedi.
You're reacting like a Sith.
Calm down.
The Sith are murderers. I know what's right. It's not evil. It can't be.
Why do you cling to the Jedi order? They will never accept you for who you are.
Forget the Jedi.
I don't care. I'm a Jedi. I've never been anything else.
Don't let the words of a fool bother you.
He was an idiot.
You're right. I need to calm down. He's, he's just too narrow-minded to see.
The return of the Sith and this war have changed things. Sometimes compromise is necessary.
Yes, I don't care what Master Cyman said. Thank you, my lord, for helping me talk through this.
My lord, I must ask a favor of you.
Our mission. We cannot hope to accomplish it without help.
I'm afraid we won't get much support from the Sith.
Allies will be hard to find.
Not the Sith. The Jedi. Yes, I know.
What are you suggesting?
What are you saying?
I'm suggesting we recruit more Jedi to our side. Yes, I know.
I don't need help from anyone.
Yes, we can.
You can't change the Empire all by yourself.
There are Jedi who would help us. Who would see that a strong rational Empire is the only path to peace.
I can see the advantages of having sympathetic Jedi when the time comes to negotiate.
That could be helpful.
Clearly you have a particular Jedi in mind.
Who were you thinking of?
Master Cyman Walz is known by many as a wise, open-minded Jedi. He brought the Sith Lord Karrus Vayl to the light and oversaw his initiation into the Jedi.
I'm cautious about getting Jedi involved too early. The Empire must want to change--they can't believe it's a Jedi plot.
That's not a good idea.
Master Cyman Walz is discreet. He's known for being open-minded, and bringing Sith to the light.
He has retired in seclusion to Alderaan for personal study and meditation, but young Jedi still make pilgrimages to him.
I would like to make a pilgrimage, and if possible, get his support.
I welcome any support we can get.
All right.
How do I know you aren't plotting against me?
This sounds suspicious.
I wouldn't plot against you. I believe in our mission. I think Cyman will support us.
I don't see why you need the approval of a Jedi.
We don't need his help.
If there's to be peace between the Jedi and the Sith, both sides must come together.
I'll return quickly, I promise.
My lord, I've been studying the Sith code lately, and I'm wondering what you think of the line, "Peace is a lie."
There doesn't seem to be a lot of room for interpretation, but I know you are an ardent proponent of peace.
You should know by now that I do not allow the Sith to dictate how I live my life.
I'm no ordinary Sith.
Yes, I guess so. It still strikes me as strange how you can be Sith and value Sith teachings so little.
There's a difference between complacency and genuine peace.
Peace comes in many forms.
The Jedi are not complacent. When it is necessary, we act.
We Sith aren't very good with rules, even our own.
Who cares about the code?
The Jedi code is the core of our philosophy. We learn it by heart and it's the foundation of everything we do.
But I guess it's different for the Sith. The Sith code is more of a description than a guide.
Some take its words very seriously.
We have fanatics, too.
Which is better: the ones that truly believe peace is a lie, or the ones with no code at all?
A Sith is the ultimate individual. There are as many different Sith philosophies as there are Sith.
All Sith are different.
We do not repress our emotions, and we embrace everything that the Force allows. That is what binds us, not the code.
The code isn't that important.
What about the Emperor? And the Dark Council? I thought they governed the Sith.
They have their own aims. That's as far as their rule extends.
Loosely.
The Emperor has not been heard from in a long time.
The Emperor is silent.
Yes, but like the rest of the Sith, they are torn apart by petty arguments.
They are all fools.
It can't go on like that you know.
How can there be peace with the Sith Empire when every Sith does their own thing?
This task we've taken gets more difficult every day.
I'm sorry about before. I didn't mean to end the conversation so abruptly.
It's just, Jedi aren't supposed to become romantically attached.
That means you're interested.
So you do like me?
Well, there's no danger of that now, is there.
You ruined your chance.
No, look, I'm sorry.
I don't want to force you into anything.
I don't mean to pressure you.
I know. I know that. You've been perfectly noble.
Jedi are supposed to be wary of attachments, but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't attracted to you.
Let's go on a date.
I'm not trying to lead you astray. But I think you're beautiful.
Well, you're lovely.
Who said you were leading me astray? Jedi have emotions, you know. They sometimes even get married.
Let's take it one step at a time.
Married? Slow down.
I didn't mean. I couldn't even imagine. Not that I don't think you'd make a good husband. What I mean is, I don't want to rush it.
Will you get a drink with me?
In that case, let's go out.
Then I know I'm not misreading you.
That's a relief.
That's sweet, but I don't want to rush things.
Of course you are. They warned you about men like me your whole life--but you've always wondered.
What Jedi could resist a Sith?
Aren't you sure of yourself?
I don't think you're dangerous. I think you're sweet.
The two aren't mutually exclusive, are they?
Can't I be both?
I guess.
Well I think you're beautiful and smart and you have a good sense of humor, for a Jedi.
So are you.
Oh. For a Jedi, hm? Tease.
Look, I've never really been out with anyone before. I don't want to rush things.
Am I rushing you?
Me neither.
No! No, I didn't mean that at all. I'm sorry, I'm a mess.
We'll go as fast as you're comfortable with.
Take your time.
Thanks. I appreciate that.
Let's just start by getting a drink.
Let me take you out.
I'd love to take you out.
Let me take you out for a drink.
Um, sure. I, um, I've never actually been on a date before. It'll be fun, right?
You have nothing to worry about.
Right.
If it helps, don't think of it as a date. We're just two friends.
Relax.
It beats standing around on the ship all day.
There's nothing better to do.
That was really fun. Thank you.
I told you you'd have a good time.
See? No reason to worry.
Always happy to please.
You're welcome.
I hope we can do that again some time.
That was the dullest night out I've ever had. Even the drinks tasted bored.
I didn't have fun.
What? Why? I'm sorry. I'll... I'll do better next time.
I know Andronikos is rather attached to the ship, but I was wondering if I could fly it now and then?
Master Ryen said I showed exceptional aptitude at flying in simulation training, but I've never been able to pilot the real thing.
You'd have to get Andronikos to agree, but I have no problem with it.
I don't see why not.
I'll be very careful, I promise.
I wouldn't trust this ship in the hands of a novice.
This ship is too valuable.
I'm not a novice! I have over a thousand hours of simulator practice!
Is there anything the Jedi don't teach their Padawans?
You learned a lot.
Not much. The Jedi Order believes in a thorough education in both theoretical and practical matters.
We join the order as young children, sometimes babies. The Jedi Order raises us.
I changed my mind. I have nothing to say to you.
I don't understand. I haven't done anything.
What did I do?
No, you didn't do anything. But you're Sith!
I thought Jedi didn't get angry.
This isn't Jedi behavior.
How can I not be angry? Didn't you hear what happened?
Well, that's a relief. I'll just get back to work then.
Fine with me.
No. You don't get off that easy.
Just released on the HoloNet. Sith in the Corellian system killed a group of free-traders for failing to give them free passage to the Outer Rim.
They murdered them.
That's what Sith do.
Sounds normal.
You don't do that, so don't tell me that all Sith are murderous psychopaths and I just have to accept it.
The free traders should've complied.
This is a war.
Who were probably weapons traders. Everyone has a side in this war.
Who were probably weapons traders. Everyone is involved in this war. Everyone has a side.
They were smugglers.
The Sith should be tried, too, but the Empire won't do anything about it, will they?
The Sith should have a trial too, but the Empire isn't going to do anything about it, are they?
Then they should've known better than to resist a Sith.
They shouldn't have resisted.
Passage to the Outer Rim is expensive. How are they supposed to make a living, or feed their families?
This rant is not very Jedi-like.
Such passion.
At least one of us has compassion for these people. Where are your emotions, Sith? Or is it all fear and hatred for you, no love or sympathy?
They can't exactly feed their families now, can they?
Can't feed anyone dead.
The Sith had no right to make those demands.
You're right.
I'm sorry this upsets you, but I can't do anything about it.
I can't bring them back.
I'm sorry, but you can't hold me responsible for the actions of every Sith.
It's not my fault.
What's the Empire going to do about it? You know the answer as well as I do. Nothing.
If there's going to be any kind of peace agreement, the Empire has to stop this.
For too long the Sith have been regarded as kings among animals. Untouchable tyrants. It will take a lot of work to change that perception.
That's a tall order.
I didn't come along because I expected things to be easy.
This behavior will destroy the Empire from within. I won't allow it.
It will be stopped.
I'm sorry. I'll try to be more patient.
It sounds like you want to make Jedi out of Sith.
A restrained Sith is not Sith.
Free will is the ultimate good, hm. Even if it results in the deaths of innocents?
Well what about their free will? Their desires? I guess they should've been Sith.
Forget it. I should've expected you'd take the Sith side.
My lord. I'm sorry I was so harsh about the Empire earlier. There's just a lot I'm still trying to process.
It's overwhelming. But you are wise beyond your years.
[Flirt] Your mind is lovely.
I don't know. I guess I've always believed that the truth is important, and that finding the truth is a life's work.
But I'm honored that you consider me wise.
Beautiful and wise are a rare combination.
[Flirt] And pretty.
Um, thank you.
I've told you about the Empire, now maybe you can clarify something for me: are all relationships forbidden to Jedi?
[Flirt] Do Jedi date?
"All relationships"? We have siblings, families. Friends, masters.
Just don't let it go to your head.
Don't get cocky.
I won't. A Jedi must always strive for humility.
You'll get used to how things work here.
You'll adjust.
I'm not sure I want to get used to it.
Let me know if I can do anything to make the adjustment easier.
I can help.
I know Jedi are supposed to be patient, but it's never been my strength.
Others will not tolerate your questions as I do.
Just be careful.
To anyone who sees us, I will be the perfect apprentice. But can you blame me?
How would you feel if suddenly you had a Jedi master and were serving the Republic?
That would depend on whether I get to see your beautiful face all day.
[Flirt] Can I be with you?
Well, um, I'm flattered.
Look, I need... I mean, I haven't done today's meditation. I need to train.
I'm sorry if I made you uncomfortable.
I didn't mean to trouble you.
No, it's alright. It's not you. I just. I have things I need to do.
Stay here with me and talk.
Don't go.
Um, no, I don't think I can.
Do you have to go? I want to get to know you better.
[Flirt] Are you sure?
Yes, yes I do. Not that it hasn't been fun talking to you. It has. But I have things to do.
Talk to you later.
Sick to my stomach.
Like vomiting.
Don't be flippant.
You came along of your own free will.
You chose this.
I did, and I accept that.
I'm sorry. I haven't been very sympathetic.
I guess I'd be uneasy too.
Thanks for understanding.
I promise, I won't let my misgivings interfere with our work.
What was your master like? You had a master, right?
I did, until I trapped her in the body of the Dashade.
She's still here. Sort of.
Ah, so that's who Zash is. The way she spoke of you, I suspected.
She makes me uneasy. She speaks so kindly of you, but the look in her eye in that body. It's wrong.
The Dashade eats Force users, and now, so does Zash.
It's Khem's hunger.
How could you have done such a horrible thing to your own master?
She is powerless to disobey me.
Don't worry.
You know you have to free her someday. You can't leave her trapped in that monster, no matter what she did.
I can and I will.
Of course I can.
If I release her, it will be to kill her.
I want her dead.
Your own master! How can you talk like that?
You understand so little about how Sith work. If I free her, she will kill me.
Freeing her would be deadly.
Deception is Zash's stock and trade. Don't believe a word she says.
You can't trust her.
My master tried to kill me.
She wanted me dead.
That, that's just insane. Why would Sith try to destroy the future of their own order?
The future of the order means nothing if you're not alive to see it.
Self-preservation. Power.
Selfishness is the real problem with the Sith order. All the violence and cruelty--it's just selfishness.
My master was not the sentimental type.
It's just how things are.
I would've tried to kill her eventually.
Don't feel sorry for me.
I won't ever get used to the fear and suspicion among Sith.
You claim to follow your passions but what about friendship? The Jedi seek spiritual peace, and they watch out for each other.
Sith don't exactly respect their masters the way Jedi do.
Masters are just in the way.
Why not? Don't you value what you can learn from your elders?
Masters Ryen and Ocera were more like parents to me than my own parents.
Yet you disobeyed them to follow me.
So why'd you leave?
Every Jedi must find her own path. Mine was with you.
They never acknowledged your true potential. They were narrow-minded tyrants, and their subjects were children.
They were fools.
But they were very wise. They were good men.
I'm sorry, I wasn't trying to start an argument. I'm still trying to figure things out.
You must've had terrible parents.
I'm sorry to hear that.
I don't remember them, actually. They died at the sacking of Coruscant, at Sith hands.
I'm very sorry to hear that.
My apologies.
It's alright. They died bravely, defending the Jedi Temple.
What do you expect me to say? Sorry? I wasn't there. I didn't do it.
Not my fault.
No, I wasn't expecting anything, just... you asked about my parents. Sarcastically, but you asked.
Now I understand why you hate Sith so much.
That explains your anger.
I don't hate anyone. But I am serious about ending this war.
Anyway, I'm sorry to bother you. I'm sure you have plenty to do.
I'm realizing there's a lot I don't understand about the Empire.
Are you having second thoughts?
Are you backing out?
There's a lot I don't understand about the Empire.
Me neither.
I don't expect a Jedi to understand. But the Empire is strength and freedom.
You'll learn eventually.
They certainly talk a lot about strength. But freedom? From what I've seen, that belongs to a select few.
Slavery is everywhere. And even among the so-called free, only the Sith act with any sort of independence.
How you can support an Empire that actively enslaves and spits on your people?
I don't support them. I aim to kill every one of them.
There's no support here.
I can understand why you're angry, and I agree that we can't abide evil, but we can't let our emotions get the better of us.
This is not the life I chose, but I'm making the best of what I've been given.
I just try to get by.
People like us need to work harder to overcome our natural disadvantages.
It's not as bad as you think.
What? Do you actually believe that you're inferior to humans?
The original Sith weren't human. Their whole attitude toward aliens is built on a lie, so they can control you.
You shouldn't have to compromise who you are. You don't have to stay, you know. You could go to the Republic.
I thought Jedi knew all about sacrifice.
Don't Jedi compromise?
We sacrifice our emotions and our fears, but not our identities.
Jedi have too many rules. The Sith may hate me, but at least I can do what I want.
No, thank you.
Might be more freeing than you think. Sure there are rules, but it beats looking over your shoulder every five seconds.
I can do far more good among the Sith than I can as a Jedi.
The Sith need good people too.
I want to believe that. It just seems like the deck is stacked against us.
They hate aliens so much. I'm worried they can only fear you, never respect you.
It's hard to see good in an empire that thinks of non-humans as nothing more than slaves.
They let some aliens become Sith.
It's not that bad.
Grudgingly, from what I've seen.
The Empire is a meritocracy. Those that can, rise to the top. The inferior fall behind.
Everyone gets their chance.
It doesn't sound as if merit has anything to do with it.
The Empire's intolerance is one of its greatest weaknesses, even as the Republic's unquestioning acceptance makes it bloated and inefficient.
It's hard to stomach.
I suppose no civilization is perfect.
I just wonder--the original Sith weren't human. It's a contradiction.
Contrary to what the Jedi teach, the world is not all light and dark. There are many shades and many contradictions.
That's the way the world is.
I'm beginning to see that, but I'm not sure I like it.
One look in the mirror and you'd understand.
But aliens are ugly.
You don't believe that--you just couldn't resist a cheap joke. Jedi aren't supposed to be vain, but I think I'm pretty enough.
I do not share the Empire's species-preference, but I am not in any place to change it, yet.
There's nothing I can do.
Yet. But that's what we're working towards, right. Maybe not a good Empire, but a reasonable one.
Can we go back to the ship and talk? When you're ready, I mean.
When you have time, I'd like to talk to you.
There really isn't much to talk about right now.
Yes, my lord.
I don't really have a choice, do I?
What happens now?
I'll be very careful, I promise.
As you say, my lord.
My lord, where do we go now?
I follow you, my lord.
I'm ready, master.
Yes, of course.
My lightsaber is ready, should you have need.
